Award.AwardTitle: Functional Organic Nanotubes from Self-Assembled Bis-Urea Macrocycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the National Science Foundation supports the work of Professor Linda Shimizu of the University of South Carolina to make well-defined, tiny 1-dimensional channels (nanotubes) to answer fundamental scientific questions. These nanotubes are prepared from simple, donut-shaped molecules that stack one on top of each other to make tiny straw-like structures. The nanotubes can be loaded with gases and small molecules without altering the channel structure. The advanced knowledge acquired leads to a greater understanding of molecular transport and could help optimize performance for industrial gas separations and the development of environmentally friendly methods to carry out industrial oxidation reactions. The educational component of this award encompasses three areas: (1) it trains graduate students in research and prepares them for future careers in science or engineering fields; (2) it supports the first research experiences of undergraduates and high school students; and (3) it broadly promotes interest in science by bringing chemists into South Carolina's K-12 classrooms to showcase the scientific method and to foster interest in chemistry and in the natural sciences, especially at high minority enrollment middle schools and high schools.

Bottom-up approaches to design functional materials through molecular self-assembly provide an efficient and high fidelity strategy to prepare well-defined nanostructures that can be used to answer fundamental questions. In this research project, the Shimizu group prepares structurally tunable 1-dimensional nanochannels by controlling the self-assembly of simple macrocyclic building blocks. These nanochannels are used for three main purposes: (1) to study the rates of transporting gas or guest molecules through the channels as a function of the channel dimensions, guest dimensions, and the interactions that can occur between the guests and the channel walls. (2) to organize molecules that can interact with light and to study the effect of this organization on their properties, and (3) to generate a reactive form of oxygen, singlet oxygen, and to control the oxidation of organic substrates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program at the National Science Foundation supported the work of Professor Linda Shimizu of the University of South Carolina applied the directed assembly of simple donut shaped macrocycles to probe fundamental questions in organic chemistry.  Much like the stacking of blocks one on top of another, these macrocycles assemble into straw-like structures or nanotubes with accessible 1-dimensional channels.  Collaborative work developed new techniques to monitor the orientation and diffusion of guests within the nanochannels. Shimizu and her group utilized this controlled assembly organize building blocks that contain molecules which interact with light and molecular oxygen. In particular, the controlled organization of benzophenone and triphenylamine containing units dramatically altered their light driven properties and generated long-lived radicals, which are species with unpaired electrons.  The research supported by this award culminated in twelve manuscripts in print and two doctoral dissertations. The knowledge acquired will contribute to improved methods for photoreactions including photo-oxidations. In addition, a greater understanding of how assembly modulates radical stability could have practical applications for new conductive and magnetic materials.  The educational component of the award focused on two areas:  (1) it enabled the first research experiences of ten undergraduates and four high school students as well as three visiting masters students and (2) it broadly promoted interest in science by bringing chemists into South Carolina K-12 classrooms to showcase the scientific method and to foster interest in chemistry and in the natural sciences. 

 

Broader Impacts:  Bottom-up approaches that use the controlled assembly of simple building blocks to give well-defined nanostructures are very powerful.  This simple strategy affords highly organized structures that can be used to answer fundamental questions in chemistry and physics. The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program at the National Science Foundation supports the work of Professor Linda Shimizu of the University of South Carolina to prepare homogeneous, crystalline assemblies with structurally tunable 1-dimensional channels. These hierarchical assemblies control the environment around discrete chemical groups and can enhance their chemical and physical properties. The Shimizu group found that organizing benzophenone or triphenylamine groups led to enhanced stabilization of their light-generated radicals.  Stable organic radicals have a wide range of potential applications in polymerizations, magnetic materials and as polarizing agents for advanced nuclear magnetic resonance techniques. Assembled benzophenone systems are of interest as catalysts for selective photooxidations using abundant molecular oxygen. The broader impacts of this project engaged seven graduate students, three visiting masters students, ten undergraduates and four high school students in research. The research undertaken provided training in a wide variety of experimental techniques including computational chemistry, organic synthesis, photochemistry and photophysics. This work also promoted science and the scientific method to the community at large through the continuation of our K-12 chemistry demonstration program.  Over the three years of this award, the program presented over 100 chemical demonstration shows to South Carolina schools and programs reaching ~3400 students.  Special emphasis was placed on highlighting science careers and in encouraging the participation of underrepresented groups through visits at high minority enrollment schools.
